    <item>
      <title>Apocalypse now for Britain’s retailers as low wages and the web cause ruin</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/17/uk-retail-industry--gloom-high-street-shift-consumers</link>
      <description>Big-name stores are teetering on the brink. Without radical action to bring back shoppers, UK high streets will be wrecked<p>“Who’d be a retailer now?” That was the comment from City economist Jeremy Cook when the latest set of grim retail sales data was released by the Office for National Statistics last Friday. “The average Brit,” he added, “has spent the past few years living by the mantra ‘When the going gets tough, the tough go shopping.’”</p><p>After a grim December, many had been hoping for a bounceback, but the figures showed that consumers were not as hardy as they once were, said Cook, and the retail sector was facing a long-term, continuing slowdown.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/17/uk-retail-industry--gloom-high-street-shift-consumers">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Unbalanced Britain needs more devolution to manage Brexit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/18/unbalanced-britain-more-devolution-manage-brexit</link>
      <description><p>With woeful productivity in parts, local authorities should decide how to spend the cash that replaces EU funds</p><p>Throughout the 1980s, a war raged between Westminster and the rest of the country that has had lasting effects. Fearing councils under the control of Michael Foot’s Labour opposition, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/local-government-network/2013/apr/09/local-government-margaret-thatcher-war-politics">Margaret Thatcher stripped power from town halls in a sweeping political land grab</a> that still marks Britain today.</p><p><a href="http://blogs.lse.ac.uk/politicsandpolicy/britains-spatially-unbalanced-economy/">London’s economy during the 1970s and much of the 1980s had more in common with the rest of the country</a> than today. It even grew at a slower pace than many other regions, but the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/oct/09/big-bang-1986-city-deregulation-boom-bust">big bang deregulation of financial services</a> in 1986 under Nigel Lawson, then chancellor, helped London’s economy to boom — aided by fat profits from investment banks in the City. At the same time, the north’s industrial base came under attack from Thatcher’s reforms, since when manufacturing as a share of national income has fallen <a href="http://cep.lse.ac.uk/pubs/download/cp414.pdf">from a quarter to just over 10%</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/18/unbalanced-britain-more-devolution-manage-brexit">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Tui's male employees paid more than double female staff – report</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/16/tui-travel-group-male-employees-paid-more-than-double-female-staff-report</link>
      <description><p>Travel group’s report says women earn 56.9% less than men but it is ‘not an equal pay issue’</p><p>The travel group Tui has the largest gender pay gap reported to date by a major UK company, with its male employees paid more than double the female staff. </p><p>Women at the group’s Tui Airways UK unit earn on average 56.9% less in hourly pay than men, according to data filed under a new government scheme intended to highlight the gender pay gap and encourage employers to address the disparity.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/society/2018/feb/16/tui-travel-group-male-employees-paid-more-than-double-female-staff-report">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>RBS looks to be in the money – but looming fine may put paid to that</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/18/rbs-in-profit-but-multibillion-us-fine-looming</link>
      <description>The bank’s reporting a profit for the first time in 10 years but its troubles aren’t over – and it’s not the only one in difficulty<p>This week should be a landmark for Royal Bank of Scotland. The publication of its annual results on Friday should mark the first time since the financial crisis that the taxpayer-backed bank has reported a profit for&nbsp;shareholders.</p><p><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2011/dec/12/rbs-collapse-timeline" title="">RBS’s dire run started in 2008, when it racked up a loss of £24.1bn</a> – the biggest in UK corporate history. The bank almost collapsed that year under the weight of more than £8bn of bad debts and £16bn of write-offs from its <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/nils-pratley-on-finance/2011/dec/12/what-rbs-board-thinking-abn-amro" title="">disastrous takeover of ABN&nbsp;Amro</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/18/rbs-in-profit-but-multibillion-us-fine-looming">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Home ownership among young adults has 'collapsed', study finds</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/16/homeownership-among-young-adults-collapsed-institute-fiscal-studies</link>
      <description><p>Chances of owning home in UK have more than halved in 20 years, Institute for Fiscal Studies says</p><p>The chances of a young adult on a middle income owning a home in the UK have more than halved in the past two decades.</p><p>New research from the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/institute-for-fiscal-studies">Institute for Fiscal Studies</a> shows how an explosion in house prices above income growth has increasingly robbed the younger generation of the ability to buy their own home. For 25- to 34-year-olds earning between £22,200 and £30,600 per year, home ownership fell to just 27% in 2016 from 65% two decades ago.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/16/homeownership-among-young-adults-collapsed-institute-fiscal-studies">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>'Parents killed it': why Facebook is losing its teenage users</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/parents-killed-it-facebook-losing-teenage-users</link>
      <description><p>This year more than 3 million under-25s in the UK and US are expected to leave the site</p><p>When Mark Zuckerberg <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2007/jul/25/media.newmedia">launched Facebook he was a 19-year-old</a> living in a dorm in his second year at university. Fast-forward 14 years and it is the young people he was so successful in luring to Facebook to propel it to become the world’s biggest social networking site that are now his biggest problem. </p><p>This year more than 3 million under-25s in the UK and US <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/12/is-facebook-for-old-people-over-55s-flock-in-as-the-young-leave">will either quit Facebook or stop using it regularly,</a> and they are pretty vocal about why. <br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2018/feb/16/parents-killed-it-facebook-losing-teenage-users">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Russian oligarchs fight mine battle in London court</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/16/russian-oligarchs-fight-mine-battle-in-london-court</link>
      <description><p>Roman Abramovich and Oleg Deripaska embroiled in row over control of Russia’s biggest mining company </p><p>Chelsea FC owner Roman Abramovich is preparing for a London court battle with two other billionaire Russian oligarchs over control of Russia’s biggest mining company. </p><p>Abramovich is being taken to court by Oleg Deripaska to prevent the Chelsea owner from selling his minority stake in mining firm Norilsk Nickel (Nornickel) to Deripaska’s rival Vladimir Potanin. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/16/russian-oligarchs-fight-mine-battle-in-london-court">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Labour is dreaming if it believes Britain wants socialism</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/labour-dreaming-uk-wants-socialism-privatisation</link>
      <description>The government might be in disarray but anxious over-50s, keen to protect their wealth and savings, have still got its back<p>At this stage of the Brexit talks there seem to be few barriers to the Tory party dominating the outcome. It’s not the string of opinion polls showing Theresa May either ahead, neck and neck or only marginally behind Labour, all of which are stunningly positive survey results for a government in such&nbsp;disarray.</p><p>Nor is it the way <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/13/boris-johnson-warns-thwarting-brexit-vote-would-be-disastrous" title="">Boris Johnson</a> and <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/06/anna-soubry-urges-may-to-sling-out-arch-brexiters" title="">Anna Soubry</a> slug it out with passion and alternative visions of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/10/brexit-theresa-may-problems-to-resolve-end-of-year-tory-leadership" title="">Brexit</a>, while Labour MPs merely lament the referendum result, stymied by a leadership that has so far preferred to play tactical games rather than put forward its preferred post-Brexit relationships.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/politics/2018/feb/17/labour-dreaming-uk-wants-socialism-privatisation">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Sky netted a sweet Premier League deal but the TV rights bubble isn’t over</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/sky-premier-league-tv-rights-deal-amazon-on-sidelines</link>
      <description>The value of TV packages may have plateaued in the UK but footie bosses aren’t worried, with the game’s appeal growing globally and the likes of Amazon on the sidelines<p>On the face of it, the outcome of the latest battle for <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/13/sky-bt-sport-premier-league-tv-rights" title="">Premier League TV rights</a> appears to be business as usual. Sky has taken the lion’s share of the best matches, extending its stranglehold on the biggest prize in British sports broadcasting to at least three decades, with BT slotting into second place.</p><p>But with Amazon in the running for at least one of the two remaining rights packages, <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/media/2018/feb/12/rupert-murdoch-pledge-keep-sky-news-independent-fox-takeover" title="">Rupert Murdoch poised to take full control of Sky</a> and then <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/27/drama-for-sky-and-disney-as-rivals-enter-arena" title="">sell it to Disney</a>, and BT calling time on its big spending on sports rights, it is a seminal moment.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/football/2018/feb/18/sky-premier-league-tv-rights-deal-amazon-on-sidelines">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>You’ve heard about the north-south divide. How about the west-east one? | Will Hutton</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/youve-heard-about-north-south-divide-how-about-west-east-one</link>
      <description>Geographical inequalities are the result of historical legacies and a fractured economy<p>Place has always been destiny in Britain, but never more so than in 2018. Pity the child born in Weymouth, Corby or Carlisle, locked into poor schools, a lacklustre economy and few decent jobs; if he or she had been lucky enough to be born in Tower Hamlets, Hackney or Westminster, their <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/inequality/2017/nov/28/social-mobility-stark-postcode-lottery-too-many-britain-left-behind-alan-milburn-commission-report" title="">life chances</a> might have been transformed. Where you are born in Britain, and England in particular, is becoming ever more a treacherous geographical lottery.</p><p>Nor is the divide any more just the well-known one between north and south. So relatively strong are the performances of Bristol and Manchester, with Liverpool hard on their heels, that overlaid on the old north-south split is the beginnings of a new one – an east-west divide. Parts of the north-west such as Trafford and North Cheshire are strong economic and social performers, while the towns along the M4 and Bristol itself are doing pretty well.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/commentisfree/2018/feb/18/youve-heard-about-north-south-divide-how-about-west-east-one">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Only the EU can break Facebook and Google's dominance | George Soros</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/15/eu-facebook-google-dominance-george-soros</link>
      <description><p>Social media giants have left the US government impotent – Europe must lead the way <br></p><p>The current moment in world history is a painful one. Open societies are in crisis, and forms of dictatorships and mafia states, exemplified by Vladimir Putin’s Russia, are on the rise. In the United States, President Donald Trump would like to establish his own mafia-style state but cannot, because the constitution, other institutions, and a vibrant civil society won’t allow it.</p><p>Not only is the survival of open society in question; the survival of our entire civilisation is at stake. The rise of leaders such as Kim Jong-un in North Korea and Trump in the US have much to do with this. Both seem willing to risk a nuclear war in order to keep themselves in power. But the root cause goes even deeper. Mankind’s ability to harness the forces of nature, both for constructive and destructive purposes, continues to grow, while our ability to govern ourselves properly fluctuates, and is now at a low ebb.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/15/eu-facebook-google-dominance-george-soros">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The old £10 note: £2bn worth must be spent in a few days</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/16/old-10-note-tenner-legal-tender</link>
      <description><p>You have until 1 March to get rid of old tenners before they are no longer legal tender – so what are your options?</p><p>There is still £2.2bn worth of the old-style paper £10 notes in circulation – but you have just 12 days left to spend them before they lose their status as <a href="https://www.bankofengland.co.uk/news/2017/november/paper-10-notes-will-cease-to-be-legal-tender-after-1-march-2018">legal tender</a> on Thursday 1 March.</p><p>The new plastic £10 note featuring Jane Austen came into circulation in mid-September, replacing the £8bn-worth of notes that carry the image of Charles Darwin on the reverse. But as the deadline draws near, the Bank of England says 218m £10 notes remain in circulation, worth £2,182m, or 27% of the total that were issued.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/16/old-10-note-tenner-legal-tender">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Self-employed?
Here’s how to 
get a mortgage</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/self-employed-mortgages-home-loans</link>
      <description>A third of people think lenders are biased against them, but there are ways to win them over<p>The number of people who are self-employed has increased dramatically since 20001, jumping from 3.3 million to 4.8 million. Do their precarious earnings mean they can’t get mortgages? Will they be treated as second-class citizens by the lenders? Sadly that will be the case for many, especially those in the low-paid “gig economy”. But don’t give up all hope: those who have more dependable earnings, and, crucially, good records of their income, can still land a decent deal.</p><p>Firstly, let’s demolish the myth that there is a category of loans called the “self-employed” mortgage. People who work for themselves are able to get the same rates as everyone else; the problem is, they have more complex incomes and must be able to prove their earnings.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/self-employed-mortgages-home-loans">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>People in their late 20s have worse credit ratings than teenagers</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/people-in-their-late-20s-have-worse-credit-rating-than-teenagers</link>
      <description><p>Figures from Experian show that people in their mid- to late 20s are the highest risks</p><p>Surveys have highlighted a worrying lack of money skills among young people, but when it comes to their credit scores, it seems teenagers are doing something right. New data from Experian shared exclusively with Guardian Money suggests that, on average, 18- and 19-year-olds have better credit scores than people in their 20s, 30s and 40s. Meanwhile, the typical age range at which your credit score is at its lowest ebb is 26 to 30.</p><p>The figures from Experian, one of the UK’s biggest credit reference agencies, show that on average, your credit score starts off quite high, when you are something of a financial blank canvas, then goes down a bit, and then goes down some more, before starting its upward ascent at about age 31. It then keeps climbing, reaching its high point at age 55-plus.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/people-in-their-late-20s-have-worse-credit-rating-than-teenagers">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Burdened by teenage kids and elderly parents, it’s grim for ‘parent-sioners’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/burdened-by-teenage-kids-and-elderly-parents-its-grim-for-parent-sioners</link>
      <description>Financial woes are making people delay having children and getting on the property ladder<p>There will be an astonishing increase over the next decade in the number of people in their 60s who have children that are not yet 18. New research suggests that in just 10 years there will be 1 million such UK “parent-sioners”, compared to 400,000 today. While no one should question the ability of someone in their 60s to care for teenagers, the financial consequences are impossible to ignore.</p><p>The rise of the parent-sioner is inevitable given how many women are having children in their 40s. Last year the birth rate among women aged 40 and above surpassed that of women aged under 20 for the first time since 1947, according to the Office for National Statistics. Births to the 40-plus have more than trebled since 1981.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/burdened-by-teenage-kids-and-elderly-parents-its-grim-for-parent-sioners">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>‘I spend £10,000 a year and most weekends on car racing’</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/car-racing-cost-motors</link>
      <description>IT consultant Steve Norton on how he lives a simple life in order to focus on his hobby<p>I’d always had a fantasy about racing cars, but it’s a hobby that needs time and money, neither of which I had enough of until five years ago. Then two random things happened that pitched me onto the track. I’d been working for Lancashire police in IT development on £32,000 a year when budget cuts meant that I was moved to maintenance programming and went from playing&nbsp;with shiny new gadgets to fixing people’s viruses all&nbsp;day.</p><p>That didn’t do it for me, so I resigned and set up as a freelance IT consultant. It’s a hard schedule – 12- to 13-hour days five days a week – but it’s doubled my earnings to £60,000 to £70,000 a year.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/money/2018/feb/17/car-racing-cost-motors">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Five top cities for business startups outside of the M25</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business-made-simple-with-vodafone/2018/jan/18/five-top-cities-for-business-startups-outside-of-the-m25</link>
      <description><p>The UK is a nation of inventors and entrepreneurs, with 75 new companies launched every hour. But don’t assume this is London-centric – regional clusters of activity are thriving too </p><p>The High Growth Small Business urban hub league table says that <a href="http://www.scaleupinstitute.org.uk/wp-content/uploads/2016/05/HGSB-report-2015.pdf" rel="nofollow">three out of every five high-growth small businesses</a> are located outside of London and the south-east of England. Not only that, they’re responsible for creating one in three new jobs – that’s up to three times the number created by FTSE 100 companies. According to an <a href="https://informi.co.uk/articles/which-city-best-start-business" rel="nofollow">Informi study from 2016</a>, London isn’t even the best city in the UK to start a business. Instead, it comes in eighth.</p><p>Choosing the right place to launch can be crucial to a startup’s success and survival. With <a href="https://www.fsb.org.uk/media-centre/press-releases/small-business-confidence-continues-to-fall-as-domestic-fears-weigh-on-outlook" rel="nofollow">almost a third (31%) of firms</a> expecting their performance to worsen over the next three months, strong local support – particularly for digital businesses – will be key. So, where is ideal place to launch? Brighton, Cambridge, Manchester, Leeds and Edinburgh are all leading the charge, from sky-high survival rates to <a href="https://mediacentre.vodafone.co.uk/pressrelease/digital-super-towns/" rel="nofollow">local digital industries</a> worth billions.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business-made-simple-with-vodafone/2018/jan/18/five-top-cities-for-business-startups-outside-of-the-m25">Continue reading...</a></description>

But it’s also a good time to extend such commitments to your startup, too</p><p>Every January, once we’ve polished off the leftovers and taken out the mountain of recycling, we get the symbolic opportunity to start afresh. We make plans, resolve to quit bad habits and promise to become our best selves. Many also use the festive period to deliberate more momentous topics, such as their careers and relationships. But can all this be done in business too?       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/09/eurostar-to-launch-london-amsterdam-direct-service-in-april</link>
      <description><p>Tickets to go on sale in February for new rail service expected to challenge airlines<br></p><p>Eurostar direct rail services between London and Amsterdam will begin on 4 April, the company has announced, in an eagerly awaited move expected to spark a price war with airlines.</p><p>Tickets for the two daily trains – starting from £35 one way – will go on sale on 20 February.       <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/08/uk-interest-rate-rise-is-coming-bank-of-england-tells-borrowers</link>
      <description><p>Decision to hold rates now came with heavy caveats that a rise is likely in May to tackle inflation</p><ul><li><a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/08/rate-rise-warning-is-sign-tackling-inflation-is-bank-of-englands-priority">Rate rise warning is sign tackling inflation is Bank’s priority</a><br></li></ul><p></p><p>The <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/bankofenglandgovernor">Bank of England</a> has signalled that an interest rate hike is coming from as early as May and that there are more to come, as the economy accelerates with help from booming global growth.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/08/uk-interest-rate-rise-is-coming-bank-of-england-tells-borrowers">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>UK high street sales stagnant amid January retail gloom</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/16/uk-high-street-sales-stagnant-amid-january-retail-gloom</link>
      <description><p>Consumer spending squeeze blamed for 0.1% rise with only gym kit and toys increasing</p><p>January was a tough month for high street retailers as sales rose just 0.1%, far below City expectations, as higher prices continued to deter shoppers from spending.</p><p>City analysts had expected a recovery of around 0.5% last month, after the <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/19/british-shoppers-christmas-spending-official-figures">unexpectedly sharp fall of 1.4% in December</a>. The figures from the <a href="https://www.ons.gov.uk/economy/inflationandpriceindices/bulletins/consumerpriceinflation/december2017">Office for National Statistics</a> (ONS) indicate a pick up in year-on-year growth to 1.6% in January, from 1.5% in December, but analysts had hoped for a bigger turnaround after a very disappointing end to last year.<br></p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/16/uk-high-street-sales-stagnant-amid-january-retail-gloom">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <description><p>Sellers of £1m-plus homes in London struggled the most to find buyers in January, survey finds</p><p>Britain’s <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/housingmarket">housing market</a> got off to a subdued start in 2018, with sellers of £1m-plus homes in London finding it toughest to find buyers in January, according to a survey of estate agents.</p><p>Across the UK as whole, the number of sales, new buyers, and properties coming onto the market all fell in January, the Royal Institution of Chartered Surveyors said.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/08/uk-housing-market-gets-off-to-subdued-start-in-2018-estate-agents-say">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Six factors influencing the UK property market in 2018</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/dec/26/six-factors-influencing-the-property-market-in-2018</link>
      <description><p>It could be a better year in Britain’s dysfunctional housing market for first-time buyers and tenants </p><p><strong>1. Interest rates will stay low</strong><br></p><p>Another 0.25% hike is expected in late spring, taking the Bank of England base rate to 0.75%. That will add £22 to the typical £175,000 tracker mortgage, but with more than half of all borrowers on fixed rates, it will probably go unnoticed by most homeowners. With the economy weak, the market does not expect any further hikes across the year. Mortgages will remain cheap although, with inflation outpacing wage rises, will still very much feel like a burden.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/dec/26/six-factors-influencing-the-property-market-in-2018">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>George Soros 'proud' of donating £400,000 to anti-Brexit campaign</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/11/george-soros-proud-donating-anti-brexit-campaign</link>
      <description><p>Billionaire says his affection for UK prompted decision, and leaving EU would leave it weaker</p><p>The Hungarian-American billionaire George Soros has said he is proud to have given £400,000 to an anti-Brexit campaign, saying it was his affection for the UK that prompted his decision.</p><p>Soros, a former refugee from communist Hungary who made $1bn (£720m) as a currency speculator betting against sterling on Black Wednesday, said leaving the EU was a tragic mistake which would weaken Britain.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/11/george-soros-proud-donating-anti-brexit-campaign">Continue reading...</a></description>

      <title>Tesco delays Clubcard changes after customer backlash</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/17/tesco-delays-clubcard-changes-customer-backlash-reward-loyalty-scheme</link>
      <description><p>Grocer postpones reward scheme revamp until June after outcry over reduced value of vouchers</p><p><a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/tesco">Tesco</a> has delayed changes to its Clubcard rewards scheme after a backlash from customers who objected to it reducing the value of vouchers without warning.</p><p>The UK’s largest retailer said on Wednesday it had listened to the feedback and would postpone the introduction of the changes until 10 June. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/17/tesco-delays-clubcard-changes-customer-backlash-reward-loyalty-scheme">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>United Airlines engine disintegrates over Pacific, forcing emergency landing</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/14/united-airlines-engine-ua1175-hawaii-san-francisco-disintegrates-over-pacific</link>
      <description><p>Passenger describes ‘scariest flight of my life’ after Boeing 777 engine cowling of UA1175 flying from San Francisco to Hawaii comes off</p><p>A United Airlines plane flying to Hawaii was forced to make an emergency landing after its engine began to fall apart mid-air. </p><p>After what was described as “the scariest flight of my life” by one passenger, photos and videos taken through the windows showed an exposed engine shaking in mid-air after the “engine cowling” broke away.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/14/united-airlines-engine-ua1175-hawaii-san-francisco-disintegrates-over-pacific">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>The Guardian's share tips for 2018</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/02/the-guardians-share-tips-for-2018</link>
      <description><p>Global stock markets hitting record high bodes well for investors as we present our top picks for the year – and hits and misses from 2017 <br></p><p>Bitcoin was the name on investors’ lips by the end of 2017, the cryptocurrency soaring 14-fold in 12 months of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/technology/2017/dec/26/bitcoin-bubble-rises-again-after-pre-christmas-rout">volatile trading</a>.</p><p>But it was also a good year for traditional investments, with <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2017/dec/29/global-markets-end-on-record-high-after-adding-9tn-in-2017">US and European markets hitting new highs.</a> Further signs of improvement in the global economy proved a positive factor, while Wall Street was boosted by Donald Trump pushing through his business-friendly tax reforms. </p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/jan/02/the-guardians-share-tips-for-2018">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>UK retail sales much lower than expected in January - as it happened</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2018/feb/16/pound-strengthens-ahead-of-uk-retail-sales-figures-business-live</link>
      <description><p>January high street performance fails to pick up after disappointing December</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-16T15:01:31.170Z">3.01pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>Despite hopes of a pick-up in high street spending after a poor December, UK retail sales came in weaker than expected in January.</p><p>Sales of <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2018/feb/16/pound-strengthens-ahead-of-uk-retail-sales-figures-business-live?page=with:block-5a86a679e4b08a79713959aa#block-5a86a679e4b08a79713959aa">gym wear improved</a> but food sales fell, according to the Office for National Statistics.</p><p class="block-time published-time"> <time datetime="2018-02-16T14:53:18.699Z">2.53pm <span class="timezone">GMT</span></time> </p><p>After five days of rises, US markets have edged higher at the start of the week’s final trading day.</p><p>The Dow Jones Industrial Average is currently up 35 points or 0.14% while the S&amp;P 500 is 0.03% better and the Nasdaq Composite 0.04% higher.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/live/2018/feb/16/pound-strengthens-ahead-of-uk-retail-sales-figures-business-live">Continue reading...</a></description>

    <item>
      <title>Interest rate rise would hit millions in UK who depend on cheap credit</title>
      <link>https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/12/interest-rate-rise-millions-uk-depend-cheap-credit</link>
      <description><p>Almost half of low-income families are believed to be in debt distress already</p><p>The Bank of England’s warning that it plans to raise interest rates from as early as May will hit millions of low-income families who have only survived financially for a decade by using cheap credit.</p><p>The Resolution Foundation said almost half of low-income families were in debt distress before Threadneedle Street said last week that <a draggable="true" href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/08/uk-interest-rate-rise-is-coming-bank-of-england-tells-borrowers">it needed to increase the base rate at an accelerated pace over the next two years</a>.</p> <a href="https://www.theguardian.com/business/2018/feb/12/interest-rate-rise-millions-uk-depend-cheap-credit">Continue reading...</a></description>
